item.description:
Inspired on Lewis Carrol's 'Alice in Wonderland'.

Players have to build roads using hexagonal tiles, move their figures across them and interact with the scenes and characters from the book in order to complete their goals.

Pathogenesis is a deck building game in which players take the role of bacterial pathogens attacking the human body. 

The game was developed in partnership with scientific illustrator somersault1824. The game is based on 100% real science and the mechanics were created to mimic how real biology works.

Avid deck builder players will feel at home playing the game as the mechanic foundation was based on several popular deck builders. The mechanics have evolved and mutated during the creation into a game that is quite its own.

The game offers several modes of play including solo play, cooperative, competitive, and team play.

No knowledge of science is required to play but it was developed to enhance the learning of the immune system at the college level.

item.description:
Introduction
				
					

It’s the Wimbledon finals, and you’re facing off against an opponent that’s every bit your equal. Will you play your best, smartest game? Know when to play aggressively? Keep momentum and use your entire bag of tricks to win the match? Big Time Tennis is the only board game that plays like real tennis. You’ll experience long volleys, dribblers off the net, service aces, fatigue-- and hit great lobs and other strokes. You’ll even be able to challenge the referee’s calls!

Object of the Game
				
					======

Use your skills, wits and a little luck to win the match and become the champion of Wimbledon!

Components
				
					

1 Game Board
 1 7-Point Tiebreaker board
 1 Scoreboard
 1 10-sided Die
16 Action cards (2 sets)
48 Momentum cards
 8 Player markers (4 gold, 4 silver)
 1 Tennis Ball token
 1 Momentum marker (double-sided)
 1 Advantage marker
 1 At-the-Net token

(I only rate my own games so they'll appear in user searches.)

Just like the classic game play of Connect 4, but instead of a flat game grid, it is a 5 layer tower - and each layer twists. Players take turns dropping a piece in the tower and then MAY twist any layer exactly one space. By doing so, at least 1 piece typically drops to a different layer adding an extra level of skill to the game. First player to get 4-in-a-row wins.

By Order of the Queen is a cooperative 2–4 player game with a fantasy role-playing game theme. Players take on the role of one of the Guilds of Tessandor, working together to dispatch Heroes to important quests, to combat monsters and to complete the Queen's Orders themselves.

By Order of the Queen is designed to give players a full fantasy campaign in one 90-120 minute game, by giving players just the highlights of a role-playing adventure.

Players must work together to keep the kingdom from falling apart while trying to complete three Queen's Orders to win the game.

item.description:
Conquer one Enemy card held by another player before someone conquers yours (2-4 players).

1)Shuffle 9 Enemy cards and give two to each player (3 if a two player game). Each player places his enemy cards face up in front of him. Remove leftover Enemy cards from the game. Shuffle the rest of the cards and deal 5 to each player. The rest become the draw pile.

2) A player begins his turn by discarding as many cards from his hand as he wishes and places them face down near the draw pile in a discard pile. He takes the same number of cards from the draw pile, always having 5 cards.

3) In time the player tries to collect any 5 that form a set listed on the Enemy cards. Divine Intervention is wild but can only be used once and never on Satan.

4) A soon as a player discards and draws, the next player takes his turn. If a player assembles a victory combination, he places those on the proper Enemy card (owned by an opponent) and declares "The battle is the Lord's" and is the winner.

Players race their vintage rocket ships through a random and mostly unexplored galaxy, encountering asteroids, UFOs, wormholes and more as they collect Star bucks to buy fuel and rocket parts. The first one to collect 3 Flags is the winner.

A deck of space cards is drawn dealt out in a conveyor belt system that creates the board as you play. Players must ration their money and fuel cards to avoid calamity. Ship upgrades can be purchased to give them an edge over their opponents. The game is random enough to be challenging without being dependent on the whim of dice.

A light racing and hand management game intended to fill a sweet spot between Sorry! and Merchants of Venus.

name.value: I See What You Did There

item.description:
I See What You Did There is a game about convincing your friends that you're clever. Convince them by relating the cards using any means of interpretation necessary.

Every card has a word on the top half and a game instruction on the bottom half. Players either use the abilities detailed on the bottom half card (ex: While this card is in play, players must repeat the last word of their sentence sentence) or try to connect 3 of their cards together (ex: Penis, Kindness, STD). Successfully convincing your fellow players that 3 of your cards are connected earns you a stack; first player to 3 stacks wins.

I See What You Did There is NOT responsible for any shenanigans you and your friends get into. (Including prank calls or murder)

Rally On is a rally racing tabletop game that uses a risk and reward dice system to play out events during each rally stage.

Rally On has been a dream of mine for the last five years. I have always been an avid rally and all around race fan. I started to design a game based on what I wanted a table racing game to be and something that I had never played before. Once, I got together with Ben M, the game really started to pick up steam. He brought the same passion I had for making a fun and exciting table top rally game. When we decided to bring on randomly laid out stages every time you play, dice driven events and a driver confidence system really brought the project to life.

Playing a different track varies the game dramatically. Never again will you have to have to play the same board over and over again or are you forced to spend money to buy a new track, just to add variety. The confidence system allows the player to push their luck with a smaller risk of an event happening, but the catch is that you only have a limited number of confidence points to start the entire rally with. The points are also carried over stage to stage, so you have to be careful not to use all yours up at the beginning or you won't have any left for later stages. This really helps to determine how hard you want to attack a turn or how fast you want to push your driver. You also get penalties for running out of confidence, so that is always on your mind. There are various ways to regain confidence points and also many ways to lose them. During Event rolls you might gain more back by taking a turn perfectly or lose a point for botching it. At the end of each Stage the players each get four driver points to spend to repair drivetrain or add confidence points. You can also use those to buy more Pace cards. Pace cards are various cards that the players can use to benefit themselves or play against their opponents. There are six, six sided dice that the players use to play out events throughout Rally On. Each die side has a unique symbol that corresponds to an event that could happen to player. Some are good and some are bad. Depending on how hard you are pushing your driver determines how many dice you will be rolling for the event. You could come out a head and gain a few extra movement spaces, shave some time off your current run, damage your car, lose time or wreck. Don't forget you always can use your precious confidence points to re-roll an event die if needed.

The goal of Rally On is to complete each stage of the rally with the least amount of time ticks. It is meant to be played as a three stage rally, but you can do less. At the start of each turn the player decides if they will up shift or downshift their gear. Once that is determined they roll the corresponding gear die. They then move that number of spaces on the stage. Each time the player comes up to a turn tile they have to decide which lane to take the turn in. Each lane has a maximum gear the player can enter in. The player has the option to attack the turn in the inside lane or outside lane. The inside lane is usually safer, but slower. The outside lane will be faster but adds a higher chance of rolling a bad event, due to rolling a higher number of event dice. This makes the outside lane a higher risk and you could potentially take damage, slide, spin off track, lose time or even gain confidence for a perfect turn. At the end of each stage the players tally their time. The player with the least amount of time wins that current stage.

Description from the publisher:

"That flaming column was spouting volcanically. The combustion does not lay warmth, but only the clamminess of death and corruption." –"The Festival", H.P. Lovecraft, 1923

In the unimaginable darkness of Kingsport, silent wanderers are called to a profane celebration. Their goal: to invoke unthinkable horrors! A dread terror that is not of this world or any other — but rather from the spaces between the stars — demands your submission. Meanwhile, unwary investigators vainly attempt to halt this appalling chapter in the dark history of Arkham.

As the high priest of one of these shadowy cults in Kingsport Festival: The Card Game, you must dominate the city. You will invoke cosmic creatures and unholy gods to receive their "gifts", but you must take care to preserve your sanity and thwart the investigators who seek to stop you. This time, you are the bad guys. Why settle for the lesser evil?

item.description:
The "Arte di Calimala" — the guild of cloth finishers and merchants in foreign cloth — was one of the greater guilds of Florence, who arrogated to themselves the civic power of the Republic of Florence during the Late Middle Ages. The woolen cloth trade was the engine that drove the city’s economy and the members of the Calimala were the elite of Florence.

Throughout its long history, the Arte di Calimala supervised the execution of artistic and architectural works. Most Florentine guilds performed such activities, but the Calimala distinguished itself from other guilds through the number and prestige of the projects and the sites administered, including the construction and decoration of some of the major churches of the city.

Players of Calimala are cloth merchants in medieval Florence, with a number of trusted employees that they assign to various streets within the city to carry out actions. (Each street connects two places where particular actions can be taken.) While taking these actions, players produce and deliver cloth and contribute to the construction and decoration of various buildings across the city. Employees stay on their assigned places for a while, carrying out their actions whenever the street is activated, and eventually are promoted into the city council, triggering a scoring phase.

Depending on the number of players, each player has a number of action discs. In turn order, they can put one on a space between two actions, performing both actions and activating all other discs on the same space. When the fourth disc is placed on an action space, the lowest one is promoted to the city council, which triggers a scoring. After the last action disc is placed or the last scoring phase in the council is triggered, the game ends. The positions of the action spaces and sequence of scoring phases vary from game to game, making each game very different. Secret scoring objectives and action cards add uncertainty.

item.description:
In a war torn land, you find yourself trying to start over, but war seems to follow you.

The world has been all but destroyed by war. You are the leader of your people, looking for untouched land that hasn't been destroyed by war. After a long journey you find this new land and you start to build a new home for your people. Other Leaders have the same idea, and the new land breaks out in war.

War Torn is a resource management game with Drafting and Building of your new city. Each player starts with a limited amount of resources to start their new home. Craft your City to match your play style, and be the first player to gain enough Victory Points to claim the land as your own.

Play as unique characters like a Lava Ape - The Fire King, or a Necromancer Crow that raises the dead. In this 2-4 player game you will find yourself building, fighting and deceiving other players to claim the victory.

Billy and Mandy really want to set up a garden in their backyard. The problem is Billy wants a garden of carrots and Mandy wants a garden of Broccoli. The only way a garden can grow is if all of the plants group together. Otherwise, the weather, animals and other gardeners can destroy the garden. In this war over the garden, there is no compromise, no surrender. You either win or become rabbit food.

This game uses the Looney Pyramids, some dice and a checkerboard to recreate the sense of total victory of your crop surviving while others fail.

Included with the Kickstarter shipment of Pyramid Arcade as one of the twelve bonus Looney Pyramid cards created for $333 level backers.

Number of Players: 2 or 4

Equipment: Timer (optional), 8x8 board, a rainbow stash per player (up to four), a Pyramid die and a Color die

Who Starts: The player who has spent the most time in a garden goes first. If it is a tie, rock-paper-scissors to see who goes first.

Setup: For a two player game, set up the a chessboard with one red trio and one yellow trio on one corner of the board just off the side of the board (they represent the carrots) & one green trio and one blue trio on the opposite corner of the board just off the side of the board (they represent the broccoli). Place the remaining red, yellow, green, and blue pyramids off the board at a neutral corner.

On the diagonal of the board in between the two players, form a line of random black pyramids. One pyramid per space. There should be an empty square at the corners of the board. The black pyramids represent the garden wall. For a four player game, set up the chessboard with each color at a corner just off the board. Form an x of black pyramids in the middle of the board. One pyramid per space. There should be an empty square at the corners of the board.

Each of the open spaces represents a part of the backyard. Place two of the same color trios off each side of the board near the opening of each of the x sections, touching the edge. The remaining trios should be accessible to the other players off the side of the board.

Gameplay: The first player rolls the Color and the Pyramid die. The player selects the pyramid based on the color and size rolled on the dice. If the dice roll shows two pieces, select one of the two pieces. If the dice roll shows the atom (*), select any color. You may place that pyramid any square on the board that does not have a pyramid already. This represents planting the seed in the garden.

If you roll black, you may move one of the black pyramids from the wall that matches the pyramid from the other dice. The black pyramid can only be moved one orthogonal space and must be no more than two squares away from the other black pyramids.

If your roll matches a combination that is already on the board, you may move one of the pyramids one square orthogonally on the board. If there is already a pyramid on that square, a player can not move into that square. If the pyramid was moved by the previous player, it can not be moved this turn.

Winning: During a two player game, the player wins when they have ten of their pyramids in their corner of the chessboard. All of the pieces must be orthogonally touching with one of the pieces in the corner of the board. In addition, all of the pieces must be on the same side of the wall. If a piece in on the wall line, it does not count as being on your side of the wall.

During a four player game, the player wins when they have ten of their pyramids in their side of the yard. All of the pieces must be orthogonally touching. In addition, all of the pieces must be on the same side of the wall. If a piece in on the wall line, it does not count as being on your side of the wall.

item.description:
Scratch is a dexterity/skill game with a hint of strategy, for 1 to 5 players.

The aim of the game is to score points by getting your fleas to jump onto Scratch the dog. You do this by skimming cards through the air to try to land on Scratch's card.

The fleas each have different abilities which can affect the points scored and there are other card types which also effect the game.

All the rules are on the cards themselves.

name.value: Marooned! A solo game of survival

item.description:
The year is 1743. The sole survivor of a shipwreck, you find yourself washed up on the sands of a small island (a 4 x 4 grid of cards). You set off to explore, hoping to find whatever you need to survive and give yourself the best chance of being rescued should a ship pass by.

Marooned! is a solo PnP game where both sides of the cards are used.

The island is gradually revealed as you explore it by placing the cards. You'll need to combine the different resources you discover to help you survive and hopefully attract the attention of the ships which periodically sail by. The map of the island, the location of items and when events occur will be different each time you play.

Be fast, be brave, be strong. You might just get to be the next King!

Animals from all over the world have come to pay their respects to the fallen King… and do battle to take his place. You’ll enter the arena against your opponents and win the crown by being the first to earn five Reputation points or by knocking out the competition.

Everyone selects and reveals their Action cards at the same time, so you’ll have to think ahead and anticipate what those other animals are thinking. Remember, a little bluffing never hurt anyone either. There are different game modes and variations to try out, so every time you seek to win the crown, it will be a completely new experience.

Sharpen your claws, bare your teeth, and prepare to fight your way to the top!

item.description: Draw Blood: Remix is exactly that - a remix of the Original Draw Blood, which was a Rummy-style card game. This revisit to the Draw Blood concept, brings back discarded elements from the earlier versions of the game, while also creating a completely new game with cards already familiar to Draw Blood fans. The result is a fast-paced game where players draw and discard their way to an empty hand, laying down a variety of Monsters that can hinder your opponent’s progress. Strategic hand management, card awareness and fun ways to stop Monsters (and your opponent) are the essence of Draw Blood: Remix.

Designer Summary

Treehouse Dreams is a card game about imagining a giant, impossible treehouse built together by the people playing the game. Each card represents a room or feature in this treehouse, and they all contain elements of who you are and the connections between you and the other players. The game is designed to ask simple questions that can reveal the deeper (or sometimes funnier) elements of who we are.

Play with people you already know, but want to know better.

User summary of play
Depending on the length of game desired, 10-20 cards are dealt among the players and everyone arranges them into a central 'tree' shape.

Taking turns, players flip cards - revealing new rooms in the treehouse and questions for the current player or all to answer. This is a storytelling game without objective win conditions.; play continues until all the players agree that the treehouse is done or all cards on the table have been revealed and answered.

Ghost hunting game where one to four paranormal investigators try to convince and prove to the town SKEPTICS that a ghost haunts a specific Environment.

Roll dice to unlock doors and match symbols on the game board, which if successful, reveals clue cards. Each Clue card has to be solved which will lead one step closer to revealing and capturing the Ghost.

Investigators have a limited time to prove the Ghost exists and claim their evidence. Environment Cards are drawn every hour which may have hazards and conditions that will try to impede the players progress.

Are you ready for a pop-culture trivia game where you have to think up the questions, your opponent provides the answer, and we rely on the Internet to settle the bet?

The handheld 69-card deck features the question prompts from popular categories like movies, TV, sports, corporations, famous people, places, and things.

You versus me, let's go.

If I played the card "US Politicians, current age," and said to you, "Donald Trump, 67 and a half," would you say "Over" or "Under"? Once answered, use your phone to look it up and settle the bet.

Switch roles, play to 9. That simple!

The circus world is full of glamour, magic, and... intrigue. Who is the best, who is the most talented?

Each player gets pair of performers and must bring both of them performers into the circus tent, avoiding the
wicked magician, so they can perform first.

Player in his turn rolls die and move accordingly avoiding the magician. Sometimes He may choose paths - shorter or longer but with ability to find useful items against magician.

The first player who reaches into the circus tent is the winner

Players are princesses who want to charm the Prince.
For this they must create the perfect love potion by collecting the most secret ingredients with the same color in the player's cauldron, while spoiling the potions of the other players with differently colored ingredients.

Players roll die and may choose and put ingredient with the same color to the cauldron with the same color so that other players can´t see the color of this ingredient. If someone thinks the ingredient is incorrect She may cry out: Charming. If You were correct You may put any of Your ingredient to the cauldron of this player. If You lied She may put any of Her ingredient to Your cauldron.

Player who runs out of ingredients may announce that the love potion is ready. The player with the most ingredients matching the color of her cauldron wins.

From the publisher´s website:

Which fairy tale hero would you like to be? The Dragon or the Princess? Lets make it a surprise instead! 
Pick a card and let the magic begin! Only the others can see who you have become, don't even try to look into the mirror! Your task is to ask clever questions and guess who you are based on the answers of the other players.

In order to guess who or what he/she turned into (what creature the card depicts) the first player has to ask questions from the other players but they can only answer with “Yes” or “No”. 
For example: 
- Am I human? Boy? Girl? Etc... The well known fairy tales can help you in coming up with the questions. If the first player successfully guesses who or what he/she has been turned into, he/she can look at the card and keep it and it is the next players turn. If the first player is unable to guess the card, you should set it aside. Before you start the game you should agree upon how many times you want to change (how many cards one player can pick during the game) and the player with the most cards at the end of the game wins!

From the publisher:

Once upon a time in a far away kingdom, there lived a beautiful princess. One day an evil witch, out of shear jealousy, bewitched her with a deep and empty slumber. The witch ripped apart the princess' magical necklace and scattered its forty pearls in the garden. 
You have to gather the forty pearls of the necklace before the last grain of sand falls in hourglass.

Player rolls die in Her turn and either pick a rolled color and place to the necklace or pick a hourglass card if die shows the hourglass.
Players win if they find all 40 pearls.
Players lose if the all the hourglass cards are drawn.

Be a fan of one of the colored contestants on the game board! You can also guess who will be the first to swim across the pool first!

On your turn, roll the color die and move the swimmer with the same color one step further. If one of the contestants acrosses the pool the game ends. Who guesses the winner wins also the game.

Pick three birds of the same color and place them on the game board! We marked their places with three colored tiles for each
color. That is where you start!

The player who can get all three of his birds to the princess by rolling die and moving before the other players, wins the game. The remaining players continue until all the birds reached the goal.

It´s raining and players race to home and can only move on from hideout to hideout so they don’t get soaked.
The youngest player goes first, then take turns clockwise! When
it’s your turn, throw the die and step forward onto the colored field shown on the die. If you threw pink, then step on the next field with a pink mushroom, if you threw green, step on the next field with a leaf, if you threw blue, go to the next field with a rock! These little drawings show where you’ve hidden from the rain. If you’ve reached the tree stump cottage at the end of the path first You win the game.

The excitement in the air is electric as the leaders round the last corner and head for the finish line. Each team has used cunning and skill to position their sprinter for this moment, but only one has done enough to pull off the win!

Will your team lead from the front and risk exhaustion? Should you play it safe in the middle of the pack? Could you surprise everyone by striking from the back? Can you time your move perfectly?

Anyone can race, few become champions!

Flamme Rouge is a fast-paced, tactical bicycle racing game where each player controls a team of two riders: a Rouleur and a Sprinteur. The players’ goal is to be the first to cross the finish line with one of their riders. Players move their riders forward by drawing and playing cards from that riders specific deck, depleting it as they go. Use slipstreams to avoid exhaustion and position your team for a well timed sprint for the win.

name.value: Escape the Room: Secret of Dr. Gravely's Retreat
Escape the room: A Szanatórium Rejtélye
Escape the Room: Das Geheimnis des Refugiums von Dr. Gravely
Escape The Room: Le Secret de la Retraite du Dr Gravety
이스케이프 더 룸: 닥터 그래블리 별장의 비밀

item.description:
What are “Escape the Room” games?

Escape the Room games began as digital adventures and quickly turned into real-life events all around the world where players are locked in a room and must uncover clues and hidden objects to escape. ThinkFun’s version of Escape the Room allows you to bring all the excitement of these experiences into your very own home!

The Mystery:
The year is 1913 and you are the lucky winner of a free stay at Foxcrest Retreat, where the famed Dr. Gravely has improved upon the latest in spa treatments and relaxation for those of high social standing. You take a long all-expense-paid train ride to the retreat. Upon your arrival, however, you and your fellow guests may find the "health retreat" is not what it seems...

The Objective:
Work with your guests to discover the dark secret of Dr. Gravely's retreat by finding clues and solving puzzles. But be careful...in the story, the doors have shut and locked behind you. Will you and your guests discover the secret and escape the room before time runs out?

name.value: Squirmish: The Card Game of Brawling Beasties

item.description:
Enter The Squirmish, a ridiculous rumble where creatures clash and only the strangest survive! Draft an odd-squad of warriors with names like Kittyclops, Pompaduck, and Killgor the Conqueror. Then position them into the melee and roll to attack. Each of seventy scrappers has its own preposterous powers, so you'll need strategy - and a bit of luck - to survive! Knock out the competition and become the beastie boss!

Contents

70 cards
 40 hit counters
 4 custom dice
 Rules of Play

Reinforces

probability
 strategic thinking

item.description:
Table Air Combat is a fast, simple air combat game that can be played on any flat surface.
Each player has a flight of fighters, represented by two-sided counters. Aircraft counters move by means of curved “performance rulers” that represent the aircraft’s historical cornering ability and maximum speed.
Each performance ruler is unique to each aircraft, and contains all the speed, cornering, and weapon information needed.
TAC is designed for portability. The entire game can fit in a plastic bag. Even the largest battles can take place on a fast-food restaurant table.

This set contains the Ju-88, which was used in the Battle of Britain and the remainder of World War II.

link.value: Table Air Combat: B-17F Flying Fortress

Table Air Combat is a fast, simple air combat game that can be played on any flat surface.
Each player has a flight of fighters, represented by two-sided counters. Aircraft counters move by means of curved “performance rulers” that represent the aircraft’s historical cornering ability and maximum speed.
Each performance ruler is unique to each aircraft, and contains all the speed, cornering, and weapon information needed.
TAC is designed for portability; The entire game can fit in a plastic bag. Even the largest battles can take place on a fast-food restaurant table.

This set contains the A6M-2 Zero. The Zero has an unmatched cornering ability and powerful 20mm cannons. Its only fault is a fragile airframe.

item.description:
Table Air Combat is a fast, simple air combat game that can be played on any flat surface.
Each player has a flight of fighters, represented by two-sided counters. Aircraft counters move by means of curved “performance rulers” that represent the aircraft’s historical cornering ability and maximum speed.
Each performance ruler is unique to each aircraft, and contains all the speed, cornering, and weapon information needed.
TAC is designed for portability; The entire game can fit in a plastic bag. Even the largest battles can take place on a fast-food restaurant table.

This set contains the A6M5 Zero. The Zero has an unmatched cornering ability and powerful 20mm cannons. The A6M5 is the most-produced variant which has improved speed over its predecessors. It retains its cornering ability with a weight half that of its arch-rival, the F6F Hellcat.

Each player has a flight of fighters, represented by two-sided counters. Aircraft counters move by means of curved “performance rulers” that represent the aircraft’s historical cornering ability and maximum speed.
Each performance ruler is unique to each aircraft, and contains all the speed, cornering, and weapon information needed.
TAC is designed for portability; The entire game can fit in a plastic bag. Even the largest battles can take place on a fast-food restaurant table.

This set contains the Spitfire V, which was was the most-produced variant and considered by many to be the definitive Spitfire. Compared to the Spitfire II, The Spitfire V has heavier armement and much greater speed, as the cost of some maneuverability. This Spitfire is in desert camouflage, perfect for battles in the Mediterranean theater.

item.description:
Table Air Combat is a fast, simple air combat game that can be played on any flat surface.
Each player has a flight of fighters, represented by two-sided counters. Aircraft counters move by means of curved “performance rulers” that represent the aircraft’s historical cornering ability and maximum speed.
Each performance ruler is unique to each aircraft, and contains all the speed, cornering, and weapon information needed.
TAC is designed for portability; The entire game can fit in a plastic bag. Even the largest battles can take place on a fast-food restaurant table.

This set contains the Ki-84 Hayate. Known as "Frank" to the allies, the Ki-84 design was a departure from the agile and delicate Zero. The Frank was less maneuverable, but was much faster and had pilot armour and self-sealing fuel tanks.

link.value: Table Air Combat: B-17F Flying Fortress
Table Air Combat: Flight Operations Manual

item.description:
Big Bad Overlord is a card and dice game for 4-6 people in which players assume the roles of evil Dukes vying to take over the world. Players gather minions great and small, ranging from Riff-Raff to Horrible Monsters, battle each other, and fend off attacks by occasional do-gooders (such as adventuring bands and small children). The game takes about an hour to play.

The goal is to eliminate all other players and become the Big Bad Overlord. Players start with six cards, half of which they can keep face-down. The face-up cards serve as the players' armies and can be used to attack other players. Each turn, players draw a new card and add it to their army. (Unless they draw a do-gooder, in which case the player has to fight it off!) There are three combat abilities - Mind control, Magic, and Melee. Most cards have at least one ability, and some have more. A successful Mind-control attack allows you to capture an enemy card; magic blows things up (especially cards weak against magic, such as the otherwise powerful Machines-O-Death); and melee allows you to chop things up.

Players fight each other using all available attacks, rolling 2 six-sided dice to determine the winner of each battle. Die rolls are modified according to the relative attack and defense strengths of each side's army in each combat category. But even the most lopsided of battles isn't in vain - a natural 12 always wins, no matter what the modifiers, and a natural 2 always fails.

In addition to the evil minions and do-gooders, the deck contains two magical artifacts. They're important because players need them to survive the endgame. When all the cards are drawn from the deck, only players who have an artifact survive. At that point, if two players are still in the game, there's a final battle in which the evil Dukes use the artifacts to smash each other's troops.

Players can gang up on each other, help each other defend against attack, backstab each other, and more. Defeat your foes, play them against each other, hoard a precious artifact or obtain one at all costs - Big Bad Overlord is a game where it's good to be bad.

The CopyCat is a word-based, hidden-identity psychology card game. Players secretly assigned the CopyCat role must pretend they know the word or phrase that everyone else carefully describes based on hints and descriptions, while the other players try to identify and eliminate the CopyCats!

At the beginning of the game, players are assigned the roles of Human or CopyCat randomly without knowing each other's identity (minority CopyCat). A Topic Card will be randomly selected for each game. The Topic Card consists of a Topic and Hints. The Humans will be able to see the Topic while the CopyCats will only be able to see the Hints. After everyone have seen the Topic or Hints, players will take turns describing the Topic (or what CopyCats think may be close to the Topic) using a word or phrase. The Humans will have to give good descriptions to prove their allegiance, but vague enough as to not give CopyCats too much information. The CopyCats will have to give clever descriptions by combining the Hints with what they've heard in order to blend in with the Humans and prevent their elimination.

The Humans must eliminate the CopyCats before 2 rounds to win, or else the CopyCats win!

Things can get pretty heated, and there is limitless potential for creativity in how to strategize.

name.value: Commissioner Victor: The lost painting case
Kommissar Viktor: Jäger des verlorenen Gemäldes

item.description:
The museum was closed on that day to not cover any tracks. The custodian, waddling back and forth on the red carpet, was plucking his hair out and quietly moaning each time he glanced at the empty space that the painting left. Guards were standing by the wall and looking at the tips of their boots. Unfortunately, the detectives did not have any good news. The perpetrator was a real pro – they did not leave anything that could lead us to him. Only those strange rumors about the man walking through the city streets, carrying a large package...

The detectives in Commissioner Victor: The lost painting case must set out to capture the art thief, and whoever succeeds will earn a promotion or mention in the local newspaper! Players assume the roles of the detectives who are helping Commissioner Victor look for the thief by using tiles with suspects' faces. The player who matches the most features of the perpetrator wins. It will not be easy though, as each player tries to prove that their suspect is guilty and will disrupt other players as much as possible. Deduction and logic needed!

Commissioner Victor: Case of Missing Alfred Worthapenny

name.value: Arthur et la Vengeance de Maltazard: le Jeu de Course

item.description:
Help Arthur, Betameche, Selenia and Max reach the passage room as fast as possible ! The future of the Minimoys is in your hands !

Playing in turns, roll a direction and a speed dice to move your vehicle as fast as possible while avoiding Maltazard's soldiers and collecting bonus cards to help you be the first to reach the end of the race.

Table Air Combat is a fast, simple air combat game that can be played on any flat surface.
Each player has a flight of fighters, represented by two-sided counters. Aircraft counters move by means of curved “performance rulers” that represent the aircraft’s historical cornering ability and maximum speed.
Each performance ruler is unique to each aircraft, and contains all the speed, cornering, and weapon information needed.
TAC is designed for portability; The entire game can fit in a plastic bag. Even the largest battles can take place on a fast-food restaurant table.

This set contains the Ju-87B Stuka, a German dive-bomber which was used in the Battle of Britain.

link.value: Table Air Combat: B-17F Flying Fortress
Table Air Combat: Flight Operations Manual

item.description:
Detective Bullshit is a game for 3-5 players you win by making shit up.

Think of Clue meets Cards Against Humanity, sort of. It's a competitive storytelling game centered around a fictional criminal case. Unlike Clue, there's no right answer, but like Cards Against Humanity, the fun is in getting your friends to pick your ridiculous story.

For each case, one player is Chief Bullshit and other players are detectives.

The Chief draws a victim card and decides the location of the crime. It's then up to the other detectives to play suspect cards from their hands and convince the Chief that their suspect is guilty. But things get complicated in the 3 rounds of each case as additional evidence, complications, and bribery keep even the best bullshitters on their toes.

From the publisher:

Flint and Feather is a 28mm, individual figure, tabletop skirmish game system of tribal warfare between the First Nations of the Great Lakes region in the legendary Pre-Contact era. Unleash your Great Warrior and assemble your Warband to raid and plunder your opponent and grow your Orenda.

Attack and Defense Card System: This unique combat system gives you the ability to choose the attack or defense maneuver of your key characters providing a critical decision point in the game during each and every melee you may fight.

Medicine Roll Initiative System: This creative initiative system allows interesting aspects of the Native American Indian mythology to be added into the game play and provides the game with more of a feel for the Legendary Pre-Contact period.

Orenda: This word is the Iroquoian name for the spiritual power inherent in people, animals and the environment. The rich Iroquoian mythology introduces aspects that allow us to creatively add magic, spells and spirit creatures to the game. Of course the wargame purist does not have to add these rules to the game if your inclination is for standard combat.

New York Bop is small scale skirmish game created by Ghetto Miniatures where you command a gang of local hoodlums looking to make a name for themselves in 1970’s New York.

Suitable for 2 or more players you will each take turns at activating your gang members to perform a number of actions. You will test your brawn against your enemies in a one on one fighting or will your gang up on the weaker enemies to take you on the path to glory.

The gang characters are represented by a detailed range of 28mm gang miniatures that each have a baseball style stats cards. All the gangs and their members have special attributes that will set them apart from their rivals who they want to get the better of.

A standard game of New York Bop is played with 8 gang members on a 3’ x 3’ surface. Games are fast paced and exciting and you can have a number of enjoyable games in one evening between friends.

Gang Warlords take control and can issue command orders to their street soldiers. You can tell your gang member to cause havoc in the streets by vandalising shops, breaking into cars and spray painting your gang logo on enemy turf in the ultimate 'Up Yours'.

Event cards in the rules add an element of unpredictability to the game as you never know when or what cards your rival is going to mess up your plans.

The rules will contain full campaign rules and map, which will allow you to fight over of New York’s Boroughs of Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens and The Bronx. You will start the campaign with a small gang and a number of turfs with the aim to expand your territory to increase your income and gang size.

As you battle through the campaign you will be able to expand your gang and upgrade member’s ranks and weapons with the income from the local shops protection money.

Draft dice and use the tools-of-the-trade in Sagrada to carefully construct your stained glass window masterpiece.

In more detail, each player builds a stained glass window by building up a grid of dice on their player board. Each board has some restrictions on which color or shade (value) of die can be placed there. Dice of the same shade or color may never be placed next to each other. Dice are drafted in player order, with the start player rotating each round, snaking back around after the last player drafts two dice. Scoring is variable per game based on achieving various patterns and varieties of placement...as well as bonus points for dark shades of a particular hidden goal color.

Special tools can be used to help you break the rules by spending skill tokens; once a tool is used, it then requires more skill tokens for the next player to use them.

The highest scoring window artisan wins!

item.description:
The poleis were the city-states of ancient Greece. Each state was like a political entity ruled by their own citizens. Your goal is to form the greatest Greek alliance, build wonders and be favored by deities.

COMPONENTS:

There are three types of cards:

POLIS CARDS, the backbone of the game, which provide resources, some abilities, Victory Points, trade routes, deity worshiping.

WONDERS CARDS, which give Victory Points. These require certain resources and once build they belong to that player.

DEITIES CARDS, give Victory Points. These require faith, they belong to the player that worships a certain deity the most - during turns these can switch among players.

GOAL:

The goal of the game is to win the most victory points.

SETUP:
The deities and wonders cards are placed face up in the middle of the table. The starting player will get two polis cards, the rest will form the draw deck.

GAMEPLAY:

During a round, a player, must draw until he has three cards in his hand. Then must choose one card and place it in front of him - once doing that he will acquire faith and resources symbols.

He then checks if he meets any deity or wonder requirements.

The round ends with the cards passed to the next player.

END OF GAME:

The game ends when all players have five polis cards in front of them, in a row.

SCORING:

Players add the Victory Points from Wonder Cards, Deities Cards, the longest trade route and any extra victory points from the polis cards.

According to the publisher, this educational card game is "designed to improve vocabularies, improve spelling and provide profitable entertainment". The game consists of a pack of 72 cards, each of which bears a single letter of the alphabet in large print. The deck has between one and six cards of any given letter.

Six cards are dealt to each player. The dealer begins by playing one of his cards and announcing a word starting with that letter. Subsequent players must play the next letter in a word on the board if they can, or start a new word if they cannot. They then draw a card from the deck to replace the one played.

After each player has had a chance to play on a word that has been announced, subsequent players may change the announced word to any other that word that includes in order the letters already played.

Players get points for completing words, ranging from 5 points for a 2-letter word to a maximum of 1,000 points for a 10-letter word. Each time a player takes a trick by completing a word, he may also "declare" another word for which he has all the necessary letters in his hand. He scores for that word as well, and then ends his turn as usual by drawing a card. Winner is first to 2,000 points.

name.value: Spanish Civil War Battles: Belchite & Teruel

item.description:
Spanish Civil War Battles: Belchite & Teruel-Alfambra is a simulation of the battles of Belchite (August-September 1937) and Teruel (December 1937-February 1938). The game uses an adaptation of the Fire & Movement system.

Each hex represents one kilometer. Each turn represents two days. Units are brigades and regiments of 3-4,000 men, and battalions of 400-800 men depending on type. Tank units represent Battalions or groups of companies of 30-40 tanks or armored cars. Support markers represent artillery battalions or squadrons of assault and bomber planes.

World at War #62 August 2018

Hidden beneath Alcatraz Federal Penitentiary is a massive, hidden research installation run by the secretive organization known as project Rising Spirit. This mysterious installation, code named “the Facility,” uses unknown energies to morph and transform itself at will to keep horrid villains, dangerous creatures, alien entities, and top-secret research projects trapped within. Rumors of the Facility’s existence and its most prized possessions have leaked, and the Valiant Universe’s most powerful organizations—The Harbinger Foundation, the Renegades, GATE, and more—are taking an interest. The world may never be the same.

In Valiant Universe: The Deck-Building Game you command an organization attempting to seize the secret Alcatraz base. Purchase cards to craft a unique deck, and battle your way through the ever-changing Facility grid that moves during play to gain access to a card or damage another player. Maneuver your superhero miniatures to battle it out with other superheroes for ultimate control!

From the rules:
"Each player assumes the role of an
Organization within the Valiant Universe,
attempting to infiltrate the Facility and gain
control while fighting off any other Organizations
along the way.
The Facility is abstractly represented by a grid
of cards: 5 Levels (rows) x 5 Blocks (columns), for
25 decks of cards. Each deck on this grid is known
as a Sector.
To gain ultimate control of the Facility, each
player will play cards from their hands to deal
damage to other Organizations and manipulate
the cards in the grid—which represents the Facility
morphing and changing. Players will also have the
opportunity to purchase cards from their Zone of
Influence (ZOI) on the Facility. Additionally, players
can move their Superhero miniature around the
Facility’s Sectors to deal additional damage to
Opponents, while making use of their Abilities on
their Power card.
Along the way, the Facility may also strike
back at the players. As fighting rages throughout
the underground complex, damage is also inflicted
not just to Organizations but to the Facility as well,
marked using the Facility Durability Tracker. As
more damage is received, more Sectors
go into shutdown, making those cards
unavailable for purchase, as well as
potentially causing damage to a player’s
Organization.
As Organizations take damage, their
Cohesion drops; a measure of their overall
strength, morale, leadership, and ability to keep
fighting. If an Organization’s Cohesion ever drops
to 0, they retreat from the Facility and are
out of the game.
The last player remaining in the game
is the winner as they seize control of the
Facility and its exotic treasures!"

item.description:
This is a promotional game released by the software company "Stackify" to entice people to demo their product.

It is a Cards Against Humanity clone, with all of the cards referring to software development and/or computer geek humor.

The rules are even expressed in scrum/agile terminology.

From the rulebook:

Occyourpation is a game of Financial Management, simulating the normal day to day costs of owning your own home and car, while at the same time running a business. The object of the came is to own your own $30,000 car, $100,000 house and have a nest egg from your businesses totaling $1,000,000!

Occyourpation is an 1978 Australian made board game made by Cassa products and is an Australian themed economic game.

In Occyourpation, much in the same vein as Monopoly, players throw dice and move around a board while purchasing objects they land on. Players however are gated on which paths on the board they are allowed to take, each path with different penalties and rewards, by their level of vehicle and income. Players are allowed to purchase shares, businesses, houses and cars aiming to earn more and more money and eventually reach the Victory condition.

Strategic board game with 88 glass marbles in three game variations

The Aim

To make a line out of marbles of your colour.

The Rules

Marbles are brought into play by sliding them onto the board from any one of its edges. Any marbles that are already there are simply pushed one space further along; however no marbles may fall off the other side of the board.

Game variations

In the game variations Shiftago Expert and Extreme, marbles can be removed from lines that have already been formed! This creates spaces along with new possibilities – but also new dangers.

item.description:
Table Air Combat is a fast, simple air combat game that can be played on any flat surface.
Each player has a flight of fighters, represented by two-sided counters. Aircraft counters move by means of curved “performance rulers” that represent the aircraft’s historical cornering ability and maximum speed.
Each performance ruler is unique to each aircraft, and contains all the speed, cornering, and weapon information needed.
TAC is designed for portability. The entire game can fit in a plastic bag. Even the largest battles can take place on a fast-food restaurant table.

This set contains the P-38L Lightning. This twin-engine fighter was fast, and maneuverable. P-38s were used in both the European and Pacific theaters.

link.value: Table Air Combat: B-17F Flying Fortress
Table Air Combat: Flight Operations Manual

item.description:
Stay Out of My Dungeon! is a semi-cooperative 4-6 player worker placement, hidden identity, building game that plays in about 60 minutes.

In Stay Out of My Dungeon! players take on the role of goblins trying to defend their dungeon from the greedy king Flumperdump. Each player, playing as 1 of 7 unique goblins, takes turns visiting and building various locations in and around their dungeon. From flame throwing turrets, to sharkodile moats, to poison traps, players must work semi-cooperatively to build each location to perfection before the King's royal guard shows up.

If all three primary defenses are constructed before the King's Royal Guard arrives, the Loyal goblin players win the game. If the Royal Guard reaches the dungeon before that happens, the hidden Spy will win.

Players achieve global and, more importantly, individual rewards for completing construction phases of a particular defensive structure. But beware! Your fellow goblins may not be as loyal as you! Each player has a hidden identity card and plays as either a Loyal Goblin, a Spy, a Selfish Jerk, or an Anarchist.

Each Loyalty type has its own win conditions. 
 - If the Royal Guard shows up before the defenses are built, the Spy player wins
If the defenses are built before the Royal Guard shows up,
 - The Anarchist wins if the Anarchy Track is high enough, otherwise
 - The Selfish Jerk wins if he/she has accumulated enough individual glory, otherwise
 - The remaining Loyal players win.

Stay Out of My Dungeon! combines the fun of hidden identity games and the camaraderie of cooperative play into one strategically rich yet easy to learn board game.

item.description:
Light family dice based game based on the Czech animation series "Pat & Mat", in Dutch called "Buurman & Buurman".

Each player has a tableau and their own set of 6 dice with which they try to fulfill jobs by rolling the tool-symbols shown on the job-cards. There are jobs in varying levels of difficulty, from 2 points (2 symbols) upto 25 points (6 symbols).

On your turn, one or more of the four jobs in the middle of the table can be fulfilled immediately or you can place dice on the cards in the hope to fulfill the job on the next turn. That is, unless someone else completes it before you or unless the black 7th die prohibits you from fulfilling the job due to various forms of bad luck which Buurman & Buurman were famous for.
Don't forget to call out "A Je To!" if such a card shows on the drawpile for an extra 5 points.

Collect 6 jobs in the tableau or a total value of 40 points to win.

item.description:
How well do you really know your friends? Find out in the ultimate party game of opinions... Classified!

Each round, one player is assigned a number 1-11, but isn't told what it is. Then, the rest of the group has to try to get that player to guess what the number is by giving a clue based on a shared prompt -- for example, "the beverage you drink on a hot day" -- in the "manner" of the number, where 1 is the worst, and 11 is the best.

For example, if it were a 1, one might say, "warm cobra venom." An good clue for 11 might be, "a smoothie made from fruits found in the Garden of Eden."

If the guessed gets it right, they get to keep the card. If they're wrong, they award the card to whomever they feel gave them the best clue.

First person to five cards wins!

Würfel-Tennis (2 players)
This game simulates a tennis match by spinning a top (or rolling a die) and moving the ball (game piece) accordingly. The ball moves from one half of the game board to the other and back. Generally two sets with up to 10 fault points are played. Only if the two sets are a draw, a third set is played to determine the winner.

Pfui Spinne (backside of the board, 2-4 players)
The players start at space 1. Movement is determined by the spinning top (or a die). If the players get on space 21 (the spider) they lose the game. The last player in the game is the winner.

Mobster Metropolis is a 2-4 player strategy game where participants compete to create the most powerful gangster syndicate. Invest in turfs and recruits to generate income and defense, or scheme and attack other players with Drive-bys to take their money. The player with the highest gangster reputation wins the game.

Each round of Mobster Metropolis is divided into phases, two major and seven short, that represent different actions and events. The structure is provides a clear gameplay and invites both new and experienced players to cunningly plan ahead for their next moves. For example, one phase lets players invest in turfs or recruits, while another is all about attacking or defending. Players will also have to deal with the increasingly tough police that often punishes the most reputable syndicate.

The game presents several innovative mechanics, like the Drive-by Selector, which let players secretly scheme and target any turf before everyone reveal their plans. The new elements are complimented by proven economic and strategic aspects of great strategy board games.

Key aspects of the Mobster Metropolis gameplay: 

 Allows a wide variety of playstyles, tactics and strategies.
 Asymmetrical setup with several elements that change for each game.
 Unique game mechanics and parts, such as the Drive-by Selector.
 The economic perspective that comes with the creation of a crime syndicate and its murky business.
 The possibility to surprise other players through card interaction and participation in events.
 The sense of scheming as all players secretly plot their attacks and defense before simultaneously revealing their plans.
 The unavoidable conflicts and rivalry triggered by Drive-by attacks.
 Card-based combat reminiscent of games like Blood Rage, and facedown token placement reminiscent of games like Game of Thrones.
 No dice.

item.description:
A deckbuilding Legacy game with the Civilization theme.

Players start with the same set of 11 cards representing their Stoneage tribe and keep developing their society, card after card. The game can be played in two modes:

Legacy mode: After the first game (Era I) players score their points and set their decks aside. The next time they'll play, each player is going to start with his own old deck and new cards will be available in the market (cards from Era II). After 5 games (5 eras), the player with the highest sum of points is the winner.

Fast mode: Use less copies of each card; players play a one-shot game purchasing cards from the market and refilling it with cards of the next eras. The player with the highest sum of points at the end of the single game is the winner.

The game mechanics are both similar and different from the original Dominion; basically, players can play a card and purchase a card from the market, as in Dominion. However, the market is a row of cards instead of different deck containing the same card in multiple copies. Moreover, there is only one type of card in the game. Each card has a point value, an effect, a cost, a colour, and can be discarded from hand together with other cards of the same colour to purchase a new card from the market. There are Leaders and Wonders too; Leaders are multicolour and have powerful effects while Wonders can be purchased at any time and they provide more ways to score extra points or other bonuses. Keep them separated from your deck.

In the Legacy mode: players choose and obtain a Leader at the end of each game, with the player with the highest score being the first to choose. Wonders can be purchased at any time (max. 1 per era) in place of a card of the market, and players keep all their Wonders until the end of the 5 eras.

Subtitled in the rules as "A Game of Family Supplies", this 1889 card game is based on the familiar mechanics of Happy Families, where players try to assemble sets of cards by asking each other for cards related to ones they already hold.

In this case, the 40-card deck is divided into 10 sets (called orders) comprised of a variety of household ingredients. Order 8, for instance, includes Prunes, Oatmeal, Cloves, Chicago Yeast Powder and Mustard.

This game has two distinct features. First, the order sets vary both in size and point value. The ten orders include four of 3 cards worth 5 points if completed, three of 4 cards worth 10 points, two of 5 cards worth 15 points, and one of 6 cards worth 20 points.

More importantly, the game has an educational focus. Each card lists three facts about the title ingredient, and three key words related to the facts on each other ingredient card in the order. If player A asks player B for the card "Citron" and B holds it, B says "What of It?" and A must then provide one of the three facts about Citron before taking the card.

This 1908 card game published in Philadelphia is based on the rivalry between Cornell, Princeton, Yale and University of Pennsylvania. The 60-card deck is divided into four suits of 15, each representing one of the four colleges. In addition to being numbered from 1 to 15, each suit contains cards with letters spelling out the name of its college. The object of the game is to complete the name of one of the four colleges using only the letters from its suit.

Players are dealt five cards each, and five more go face-up on the field between them. Each player on his turn has the opportunity to capture cards on the field by playing a card that adds up to the same number (e.g. a 13 can be played to capture a 9 and 4). He plays until unable to capture any more, and then adds one of the cards from his hand to the field. When a player exhausts his hand, he gets a new hand of five cards.

Players must declare which college they are playing for, and if there is competition for one, the first player to get the 15 of that suit takes over and the other player must go after a different college.

Letter cards of the desired college are placed in front of the player as successfully used or captured, and the remaining cards go into a discard stack which becomes the replacement deck when needed. While two colleges have only four letters (PENN and YALE), the values of the letter cards ensure that each college is as hard to complete as the others (e.g. PENN has letter cards of 12, 13, 14 and 15, while PRINCETON includes 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 9 and 15).

I have met a young noble while traveling. It seemed that he has everything anyone could ever want: son of a wealthy prince and highlander, descending from the famous winemakers, heir to the fortune, chief to the conscript army of the east flank, university scholar, educated, handsome and desired by ladies of all ages... And somehow there was always some kind of melancholy and sorrow written on his face. Once during shared meal, the noble confessed what grieves him: he never tasted what real adventure is. He heard tales of heroes and journeys – he wanted it himself but did not know how to begin. So I helped him by taking him to the Adventure's Gate, notorious inn where you can find adventurers ready to brave the world.

And this is how it begins...

Tavern Tales is a card-game in which players build their decks on their own. Their deck consists of adventurers who crave fame and, well, adventure. Each of 15 characters in the game possesses their own unique ability, so the choice of characters that the players recruit has direct impact on their win chance. You need to choose your party members so their abilities complement each other. Although rules are easy, winning the game is not. Players have to demonstrate their strategic thinking, long-term planning, and ability to react to the other players' moves.

The game is divided into nine rounds. In each round, each player performs their turn. During this turn, player must perform two out of three available actions


 Play a card face-up and use its ability.
 Play a card face-down and recruit a character or take on a quest.
 Play a set of cards from the same character.


Thanks to synergy between cards, players try to recruit as many characters as possible and complete as many quests as possible. At the end of the game, players earn prestige points for characters met during the game and for completed quests.

item.description:
Squirrel Rush is a tale of forest tricksters who are so busy climbing trees and hiding in holes. and engaging in fun and games that they forgot about building food reserves for winter! They have only one day left to gather nuts, acorns and chestnuts from the forest glade, which has all kinds of nuts hidden under a blanket of autumn leaves, which means that only cunning creatures can find them all!

Before starting, players build the glade playing area from tiles. During play, players help the squirrels gather reserves for winter. Using wits and logical reasoning, they have to choose the best way to act — the best way meaning whatever brings in the most food! Players can use various special actions to help them achieve their goal.

item.description:
Table Air Combat is a fast, simple air combat game that can be played on any flat surface.
Each player has a flight of fighters, represented by two-sided counters. Aircraft counters move by means of curved “performance rulers” that represent the aircraft’s historical cornering ability and maximum speed.
Each performance ruler is unique to each aircraft, and contains all the speed, cornering, and weapon information needed.
TAC is designed for portability; The entire game can fit in a plastic bag. Even the largest battles can take place on a fast-food restaurant table.

Each aircraft is sold separately. This set contains the Bf-109E, which was used in the Battle of Britain.

link.value: Table Air Combat: B-17F Flying Fortress
Table Air Combat: Flight Operations Manual

item.description:
Table Air Combat is a fast, simple air combat game that can be played on any flat surface.
Each player has a flight of fighters, represented by two-sided counters. Aircraft counters move by means of curved “performance rulers” that represent the aircraft’s historical cornering ability and maximum speed.
Each performance ruler is unique to each aircraft, and contains all the speed, cornering, and weapon information needed.
TAC is designed for portability; The entire game can fit in a plastic bag. Even the largest battles can take place on a fast-food restaurant table.

This set contains the Bf-109F, which entered service in 1941. It has greater speed than the Bf-109 and greater maneuverability than the later Bf-109G. This version is colored in desert camouflage, suitable for combat in the Mediterranean theater of operations.

Each player has a flight of fighters, represented by two-sided counters. Aircraft counters move by means of curved “performance rulers” that represent the aircraft’s historical cornering ability and maximum speed.

TAC is designed for portability; The entire game can fit in a plastic bag. Even the largest battles can take place on a fast-food restaurant table.

name.value: The Robot That Totally Saved Cleveland

item.description:
Using a 5 card hand, players take turns attempting to build a robot that will be used to defeat the Evil Dr. Head Case and his Mutant Monsters.

The robots are made up of three cards. A head card, a body card, and a feet card. The cards work together to build robots in fun combinations. As the players build the robots, they can end up with names like "A funkyâ€right ol'â€pulverizer" or "Mr Electric theâ€crushingâ€bubble bot". Players also have the option of attaching 1 addâ€on card to the robot. The addâ€on cards are things like "Lazers for Eyes", "Bulletproof Boots", and "Razor Sharp Dentures".

The game is quick and simple to learn. Once the players have a round or two under their belt the game is fun and everyone enjoys building the robots.

There are a few other features to the game like the "Bargain Center" which allows players to grab a "Crumpled" head, or an "As seen on tv" body part to finish out their robot in a pinch. Using the bargain center parts might seem like a disadvantage but be careful. That player might be holding the "Dick Jone's Rust Remover" card which allows them to polish it up and make it shiny and new.

A traditional dexterity game, Climbing Path involves carefully moving a ball up the face of a sloped wall full of holes, trying to avoid the holes in order to reach the destination, by means of pulling on two strings attached to a ball carrier. Suggested paths printed on the board can be followed for varied difficulty, or you can attempt your own path. This is similar to the dexterity game Labyrinth, but this one is vertical, and uses strings to move the ball, instead of tilting the board.

Ultra•Quest is a roleplaying-board-game in which you play a group of four intrepid adventurers. In just ten minutes you create your very own group from eight races (humans, elves, dwarves, halflings, half-elves, half-orcs, centaurs and half-ducks) and six professions (fighter, ranger, thief, seafarer, cleric and wizard).

Your heroes roam the dangerous realms of Ultimor in search of adventure, Ruhm! (fame/XP), Ehre! (glory) and of course: gold.

You will be the kings personal heroes and thus attain knighthood upon amass a enough Ehre! (glory) or finding one of the legendary treasures!

Bewarned though: It may take hours or even days to complete this goal and you may even fail at the last instant.
---

Ultra•Quest ist das Rollen-Brettspiel, bei dem Du eine Gruppe unerschrockener Abenteurer spielst. Wähle zu Beginn aus 8 Rassen und 6 Berufen Deine unverwechselbare Gruppe. Die Erschaffung dauert nur 10 Minuten. Tauche ein in die fantastische Welt von Ultra•Quest!

Deine vier wackeren Recken streifen durch das Königreich Ultimor, stets auf der Suche nach Abenteuern, denn die verheißen Gold, Ruhm! und Ehre! Sammle wichtige magische Gegenstände und werde mächtiger. Aber sei auf der Hut! Überall lauert die Gefahr! Handle klug, dann findest Du am Ende Deiner Queste vielleicht den legendären Schatz und wirst zum ewigen Helden von Ultimor!
Viel Glück, Reisender, viel Glück!

link.value: UltraQuest: Gold, Ruhm! und Ehre! – Der Oger Character Expansion

name.value: Lord of the Fries: McPubihan's Irish Pub Deck

item.description:
This is an 54 card expansion deck for Lord of the Fries continuing the Zombies working in a restaurant theme to an Irish Pub. Ingredients: bread, potatoes, stout, whiskey. veggies, cow meat and fish meat are combined in various humorously renamed Irish recipes.

The mechanics are essentially the same as the base game with the addition of the "stew pot" a collection of face-up cards created by a discard of a single card by each player after the initial deal. Players may, on their turn, exchange one card with one from the stew pot prior to filling an order.

Besides being an expansion to Lord of the Fries, this can be played as a stand alone.

Leader, Speedy and Strongman make a great team! Develop a strategy to stock up on nuts by playing to your team strength!

Squeeerrels is a simple game about squirrels gathering nuts. The gameplay consist of three stages.

Stage one - Exploring
The cards are shuffled and organised in 4 or 5 piles (depending on the number of players). Now each player may view the cards of one forest and the last player may view two forests.

Stage two - To the forest
Players in turn order assign all of their squirrels one at a time.

Stage three - Collecting the nuts
All forest cards are revealed. At first every hedgehog takes one nut. Now the squirrels take what's left unless the marten prevents them. The squirrels may also use their special abilities. Speedy may take a nut before hedgehog takes one. Strongman may take two nuts instead of one. Leader may change forests with one its teammates.

After 3 or 4 rounds (depending on number of players) the game ends. The person who has the highest number of nuts is the winner and Squeeerrel The Strategist!
